data.text: How does trust in a central bank affect people’s inflation expectations? Our guest @Siria_Angino talks about how trust from the public helps the ECB to deliver on its mandate in the latest episode of The ECB #Podcast https://t.co/DgQnOQz0KL https://t.co/kaQ5nkciu8

We should never underestimate the political commitment to the euro, says Financial Times’ @martinwolf_ to our host @michaelsteen. Listen to The ECB #Podcast, subscribe and let us know what you think https://t.co/DgQnOQz0KL https://t.co/fazz6fTba3

Have you listened to the latest episode of our podcast yet? Our host @michaelsteen talks to behavioural economist @Siria_Angino about people’s support for the euro and trust in the ECB https://t.co/DgQnOQz0KL https://t.co/k9ugS8uQ16
ECB will directly supervise 117 banks in 2020 https://t.co/W2zZlhKJ55
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Oct 2019) https://t.co/UFgnmFdgre
ECB sanctions Natixis Wealth Management Luxembourg for breaching large exposures limit and large exposures reporting requirements in 2016 and 2017 https://t.co/fUZ8uqsRby
Cœuré: The risk is high that Europe will once again fail to fix its roof when the sun is shining https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 6/6

Cœuré: Intergovernmental decision-making may be politically convenient in the short term, but it carries a high economic cost in the longer run. It favours procrastination and it turns every decision into a zero-sum game https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 5/6
Cœuré: The increasing complexity of the Stability and Growth Pact and the politicisation of its enforcement have not served us well https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 4/6
Cœuré: A capital markets union cannot function without European-level supervision of systemic intermediaries and infrastructures https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 3/6

Cœuré: Completing the Single Market is a central pillar in our efforts to boost productivity growth. It will make our monetary union more resilient and support the normalisation of real interest rates towards higher, positive levels https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 2/6 https://t.co/eboAAinSxs
(THREAD) The euro area architecture is still not crisis-proof, says Executive Board member Benoît Cœuré in Brussels. Read his full speech here https://t.co/Wx3kH0SR61 1/6
Working paper: Financial cycles, credit bubbles and stabilization policies https://t.co/Grrgaom1rr
Working paper : Merging structural and reduced-form models for forecasting: opening the DSGE-VAR box https://t.co/n8ZK8AABqf

Lagarde: The last European elections highlighted that people expect ambitious responses from Europe. Matching these expectations by working together is the best way to strengthen people’s confidence in the European project, the euro and the ECB. (10/10) https://t.co/qtG6FDIaXb

Lagarde: We play our part, in full independence, in assessing the value of central bank digital currencies for European citizens and the broader economy. Our ultimate goal is to foster safer, innovative and integrated payments in euro. (9/10)

Lagarde: Since 2016, the ECB has been exploring the application of new technologies, particularly distributed ledger technologies, to market infrastructures. But driving change also means identifying and managing the risks that come with breaking new ground. (8/10)

Lagarde: Last year, the ECB launched TARGET Instant Payment Settlement (TIPS), an instant payment service that allows money to reach the recipient within seconds, 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. TIPS increases the speed and safety of customers’ daily transactions. (7/10)

Lagarde: The macroeconomic landscape has changed and new challenges such as demographics, disruptive technology and climate change have emerged. This calls for us to review our strategy and consider how our monetary policy can best deliver on our mandate. (5/10)

Lagarde: The ECB’s accommodative policy stance has been a key driver of domestic demand during the recovery, and that stance remains in place. Monetary policy will continue to support the economy and respond to future risks in line with our price stability mandate. (4/10)

Lagarde: I look forward to a constructive and positive relationship between our two institutions going forward. The connection between the ECB and the European Parliament is especially valuable today as a means to reinforce trust in European institutions. (3/10)

Lagarde: Communication is a two way street and it is vitally important for democracy, a founding principle of Europe. It is in this spirit that I will approach this hearing – and those we will have together in the future. (2/10)

(THREAD) The ECB remains resolute in its commitment to deliver on its mandate, says President Christine Lagarde at her first quarterly hearing before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN. (1/10) https://t.co/qtG6FDIaXb
Working paper: Firm-level employment, labour market reforms, and bank distress https://t.co/XLoXQ0f8kI

The euro turned 20 this year. In the latest episode of our #podcast, Erkki Liikanen (@LiikanenErkki), former Governor of @SuomenPankki – Finlands Bank, discusses the last two decades of the euro and looks ahead to the future with our host @michaelsteen https://t.co/DgQnOQz0KL https://t.co/MedVQl5yZe

Support for our single currency is at an all-time high. 76% of people in the eurozone think that the euro is good for the EU, the latest Eurobarometer survey shows. See the full results here https://t.co/gseJTZpBSP https://t.co/Unk7MKpXHG

Where will the euro be in the next 20 years? @michaelsteen  discusses this and other questions with Erkki Liikanen (@LiikanenErkki), @martinwolf_ and @Siria_Angino in the latest episode of The ECB #Podcast. Listen, subscribe and let us know what you think https://t.co/DgQnOQz0KL https://t.co/5lDHLIPQr4

Equity investment can play an important role in the transition to low-carbon economies, in particular by stimulating innovation that leads to the adoption of greener technologies. Find out more in our recent working paper https://t.co/cdqg6zsKNB

If a country wants to decarbonise its economy, it should not only promote green finance initiatives such as green bonds, but also develop its equity markets. That’s a conclusion from our latest Research Bulletin https://t.co/j8zqSZMltE https://t.co/GkeUMJ3y5P

We are one year old on Instagram today! Have you checked out our account yet?
Discover what we do here at the ECB, uncover the hidden features of euro banknotes and find out what on earth porridge, inflation and central banks have in common. Take a look https://t.co/XbinbForna https://t.co/lCRvnEIswU
Speech Edouard Fernandez-Bollo: Financial markets and the digital revolution https://t.co/Xj9jLiOQ6M
Benoît Cœuré: Potential central bank initiatives should not discourage private market-led solutions for retail payments in the euro area https://t.co/d8sxyMuvTM
Benoît Cœuré: A central bank digital currency could ensure that citizens remain able to use central bank money even if electronic payments become even more popular https://t.co/d8sxyMuvTM
Benoît Cœuré: Strategic autonomy in payments is part of the European agenda to assert the euro’s international role https://t.co/d8sxyMuvTM

The ECB welcomes the strategic initiative of a number of major European banks to create a true pan-European retail payment solution, says Executive Board member Benoît Cœuré at a joint ECB-National Bank of Belgium conference @NBB_BNB_NL @NBB_BNB_FR https://t.co/d8sxyMuvTM
Speech Yves Mersch: From Basel III to European banking regulation https://t.co/24fJB71fvW
Speech Philip R. Lane: The yield curve and monetary policy https://t.co/YZKqMYj65i

Luis de Guindos: To successfully meet the aims of the Paris Agreement, we need to see changes in how funding flows to the real economy. In the EU, this adds a further environmental motivation to the already substantial merits of completing the capital markets union.

Luis de Guindos: When it comes to financing new technologies, equity funding may prove more appropriate than bank lending. Equity investors typically have a longer investment horizon and a greater appetite for high-risk projects that have high potential returns.

Luis de Guindos: We are studying the potential impact of climate-related risks for the euro area financial system. We are currently developing an analytical framework for carrying out a climate risk stress test analysis for the euro area banking sector https://t.co/s2EkssurQ1

The necessary transition to a low-carbon economy entails risks for the financial system that are insufficiently understood, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. Correctly assessing these risks requires a higher quantity and quality of disclosures https://t.co/VCW0g4fXXI
Lagarde: A completed Economic and Monetary Union will balance risk reduction and risk sharing. This would tap into new sources of growth. (6/6) https://t.co/0gvthzCgam

Lagarde: We need a new policy mix for a common future that is more productive, more digital and greener. National policies and European programmes can help boost investment and empower our internal market. (5/6)

Lagarde: Monetary policy will continue to support the economy and respond to future risks in line with our price stability mandate. And we will continuously monitor the side effects of our policies. Our policy will undergo a strategic review in the near future. (4/6)

Lagarde: We need the world’s second largest economy to be open to the world but confident in itself – to make full use of Europe’s potential to unleash higher rates of domestic demand and long-term growth. (3/6)

Lagarde: The euro area faces two challenges in the global economy: the changing nature of world trade and the growth slowdown in advanced economies. Domestic growth is slowing due to productivity, ageing and weak domestic demand. (2/6)

(THREAD) We need to strengthen our common institutions and empower the European economy to respond to today’s challenges, says President Christine Lagarde in her speech at the European Banking Congress. (1/6) https://t.co/0gvthzCgam

We’ve published the minutes 16 Oct meeting of the Working group on risk-free rates. Topics discussed were communication & education, updates regarding the work on fallback rates for Euribor and the development of a liquid €STR market, among other things https://t.co/ViRjWbrYg1

On the whole, all the tools for proportionate regulation and supervision of European banks are in place, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. The share of high-yield and lower-rated investment-grade debt has risen in recent years. Such debt is often issued by highly leveraged firms, which are more likely to be downgraded during economic downturns. This vulnerability needs to be monitored closely https://t.co/uBeFD17zr0 https://t.co/q93vragjPu

We look at policies aimed at addressing the specific drivers of underperformance and reducing overcapacity without excessively increasing big banks’ market power. Euro area banks should become leaner, more digital and more agile to reduce costs and boost profitability. 3/3

Underperforming banks often struggle with legacy asset problems, weak income generation or combined cost and revenue problems. Consolidation can help address the latter two issues https://t.co/vcMZNd6HzX 2/3

(THREAD) Much of the weakness in overall euro area bank profitability can be explained by the persistent underperformance of some banks that have high cost-to-income ratios. What strategies could address the root causes? https://t.co/vcMZNd6HzX 1/3 https://t.co/c1IurXyrn8
